question: Question_11
hints:
What is the dimension of the least square solution vector
\textbf{\emph{x}}?

The equation \emph{A\textbf{x} = \textbf{b}} is overdetermined, and does
not have a solution. What we mean by \emph{least square solution
\textbf{x}} is the vector $\hat{\mathbf x}$ that satisfies

\begin{align*}\|A\hat{\mathbf x} - \mathbf b\|^2 = \text{min}_{\mathbf{x} \in \mathbb{R}^2} \|A \mathbf x - \mathbf b\|^2\end{align*}

Now that you know $\hat{\mathbf x}$ it is time to look at how the matrix
\emph{A} and the vector \textbf{\emph{b}} were chosen. How does this
relate to the equation of a line

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
y = mx + t\end{align*} Consider each of the four points, one at a time.
